'''Peter James Donnelly''', [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] [[FMedSci]] (born 15 May 1959) is an Australian  [[mathematics|mathematician]] and Professor of Statistical Science at the [[University of Oxford]]. He is a specialist in [[applied probability]] and has made contributions to [[coalescent theory]].  His research group at Oxford has an international reputation for the development of statistical methodology to analyze genetic data.

== Background, family and education ==

Donnelly was born and raised in Brisbane, Queensland, the son of financial adviser, economic theorist and author Austin Donnelly<ref>Way, Nicholas (2007), ''[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]'', 6 September 2007 Obituary http://www.smh.com.au/news/obituaries/foe-to-fund-managers-and-tireless-campaigner-for-small-investors/2007/09/05/1188783315224.html</ref> and Sheila Donnelly. He is the brother of Sharon Donnelly and of eminent Australian financier, funds manager and company director Melda Donnelly.<ref>[http://investing.businessweek.com/research/stocks/private/person.asp?personId=39333786&privcapId=3675711 ''Bloomberg Businessweek'' Company Overview of Victorian Funds Management Corporation]; Retrieved 9 January 2015.</ref> He was educated at [[St Joseph's College, Gregory Terrace|St. Joseph's Christian Brothers College, Gregory Terrace]], the [[University of Queensland]] and [[Balliol College, Oxford]].

== Professional life ==

When elected to a chair at [[Queen Mary, University of London|Queen Mary College, London]] in 1988 Donnelly was only 29,<ref>[http://www.stats.ox.ac.uk/people/academic_staff/peter_donnelly/cv Peter Donnelly's CV]</ref> and possibly the youngest Professor in Great Britain. He held a chair at the [[University of Chicago]] (1994–96) and was head of the Department of [[Statistics]] at the [[University of Oxford]] from 1996 to 2001. Since 2007, he has been Director, [[Wellcome Trust Centre for Human Genetics]] (WTCHG) in Oxford, where he is currently based. He is a fellow at [[St Anne's College, Oxford]].

Many leading statistical geneticists worked with Donnelly as young researchers including [[David Balding]], [[Carsten Wiuf]], [[Matthew Stephens (statistician)|Matthew Stephens]] and [[Jonathan Pritchard]]. One area in which he has a leading reputation is in the interpretation of [[DNA]] evidence. He has acted as an [[expert witness]] on [[forensic science]] in criminal trials.<ref>{{citation|title=Truth Machine: The Contentious History of DNA Fingerprinting|first1=Michael|last1=Lynch|first2=Simon A.|last2=Cole|first3=Ruth|last3=McNally|first4=Kathleen|last4=Jordan|publisher=University of Chicago Press|year=2010|isbn=9780226498089|page=193|url=http://books.google.com/books?id=EVmr3kyB7ewC&pg=PA193}}.</ref>

He is noted for his collaborative work with [[biology|biologists]]. He has been heavily involved in a number of large scale projects, such as the [[International HapMap Project]]<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.the-scientist.com/?articles.view/articleNo/23483/title/Phase-I-of-HapMap-Complete/|title=Phase I of HapMap Complete: International consortium publishes most comprehensive catalog of human genetic variation to date|journal=The Scientist|date=26 October 2005|first=David|last=Secko}}.</ref> and the Wellcome Trust Case Control Consortium, a [[genome-wide association study]].<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.aaojournal.org/cms/attachment/2005813564/2025507726/|journal=Ophthalmology|title=List of Contributing Investigators: Membership of Wellcome Trust Case Control Consortium 2|accessdate=2014-09-18}}.</ref>

== Awards and honours ==

Donnelly was elected a [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] in 2006<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.st-annes.ox.ac.uk/about/news/item/article/professor-donnelly-elected-fellow-o|title=Professor Donnelly elected Fellow of The Royal Society|publisher=St. Anne's College, University of Oxford|date=1 June 2006}}</ref> and also elected as a Fellow of the [[Academy of Medical Sciences]] in 2008.<ref>{{citation|url=http://www.ox.ac.uk/media/news_stories/2008/080502.html|title=New Fellows elected to Academy of Medical Sciences|publisher=University of Oxford|date=2 May 2008}}.</ref>

Other significant awards and honours have included:<ref name="stats.ox.ac.uk">Department of Statistics, University of Oxford, Academic Staff, Peter Donnelly http://www.stats.ox.ac.uk/people/academic_staff/peter_donnelly/cv</ref>

* 1980  University Medal, [[University of Queensland]]
* 1980-1983  [[Rhodes Scholarship]]
* 1984-1985  [[University of Wales]] Research Fellowship
* 1988 Elected Ordinary Member of the [[International Statistical Institute]]
* 1990  Special Invited Lecturer, [[Institute of Mathematical Statistics]]
* 1990-1995  SERC Advanced Fellowship
* 1995  Elected Fellow of the [[Institute of Mathematical Statistics]]
* 1999  Elected Honorary Fellow, [[Institute of Actuaries]]
* 2000  Bernoulli Lecturer, 5th World Congress of the [[Bernoulli Society]]
* 2001 Forum Lecturer, European Meeting of Statisticians
* 2002 Editor’s Invited Paper, Statistical Society of Australia
* 2002 Mitchell Prize, of the [[American Statistical Association]] and ISBA
* 2004 Guy Medal in Silver, [[Royal Statistical Society]]
* 2007 Medallion Lecturer, [[Institute of Mathematical Statistics]].
* 2007 The main paper from the [[Wellcome Trust]] Case Control Consortium, which Donnelly chaired, won several awards, including ''[[The Lancet]]'' 's Paper of the Year, ''[[Scientific American]]'' 's Research Leader of the Year, the Amadeus Prize, and one of Nature's Editor's Picks for 2007.
* 2009 Awarded the [[Weldon Memorial Prize]] <ref name="stats.ox.ac.uk"/>
